title: Part B Interpretation
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn this point present an interpretation that addresses how the passage depicts a character trait of Athenodorus after he rents the house.
descriptions:
The response does not present an interpretation that responds directly to the prompt.

Question B: In 3 to 4 complete sentences, identify a character trait Athenodorus displays in lines 3-7 (Ubi…fingeret) after renting the house and explain how that trait is depicted in the passage.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Athenodorus’s calm actions after renting the house depict his bravery.”

  • “By facing the haunted house alone, the passage depicts Athenodorus as selfless.”

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • Restate the prompt without responding to it.

  • Respond to a related but different prompt.

  • Do not respond to any single prompt.

The response presents an interpretation that responds directly to the prompt.

Question B: In 3 to 4 complete sentences, identify a character trait Athenodorus displays in lines 3-7 (Ubi…fingeret) after renting the house and explain how that trait is depicted in the passage.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Athenodorus’s calm actions after renting the house depict his bravery.”

  • “By facing the haunted house alone, the passage depicts Athenodorus as selfless.”

Additional Notes:

  • The interpretation may be anywhere within the response.

  • An interpretation that meets the criteria can be awarded the point regardless of whether or not the provided Latin citations and explanations successfully support the interpretation.

title: Part B Latin Citation
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn one point:

  • Present a citation that exhibits a partially accurate understanding of the cited Latin.

  • Present a citation that, while not wholly inaccurate, contains significant errors and/or reflects a weak understanding of the Latin.

  • Present a citation that is no more substantive than a single Latin word or short phrase taken out of context.

Responses that earn two points:

  • Present a citation that exhibits an accurate understanding of the cited Latin.

  • Present a paraphrase or translation of cited Latin that may contain, at most, minor errors that do not detract from the response.

  • Present a citation that is more substantive than a single Latin word or a short phrase taken out of context.
descriptions:
The response provides no Latin citation or one that is wholly incorrect from the provided Latin text to support the response.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Athenodorus sets his mind to writing in order to avoid imagining something happening that isn’t (ipse ad scribendum…metus fingeret).”

  • “Athenodorus plans to spend the night in the front of the house (iubet…parte) but sends everyone else away (suos omnes…dimittit).”

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • Cite no Latin.

  • Present a citation, but the citation exhibits no understanding of the Latin.

  • Present a citation, but the citation exhibits a complete misunderstanding of the Latin.

The response provides one partially correct Latin citation from the provided Latin text to support the response.

Examples that earn one point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Athenodorus sternly orders that his stylus and tablets be set up in the front part of the house (iubet sterni sibi in prima domus parte).”

  • “When night falls, Athenodorus gets his tablet and stylus (pugillares stilum).”

Additional Notes:

  • Additional citations, whether accurate or not, do not affect the points awarded. (If there are multiple citations, some accurate but others not, points should be awarded for the 1 accurate citation.)

The response provides one correct Latin citation from the provided Latin text to support the response.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Athenodorus sets his mind to writing in order to avoid imagining something happening that isn’t (ipse ad scribendum…metus fingeret).”

  • “Athenodorus plans to spend the night in the front of the house (iubet…parte) but sends everyone else away (suos omnes…dimittit).”

Additional Notes:

  • Additional citations, whether accurate or not, do not affect the points awarded. (If there are multiple citations, some accurate but others not, points should be awarded for the 1 accurate citation.)

title: Part B Explanation
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Responses that earn one point:

  • Provide an explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the passage’s characterization of Athenodorus.

  • Do not go beyond mere summary of the cited Latin in the explanation.

  • Display only limited understanding of the implied information in the Latin citation and/or make inaccurate inferences in the explanation.

Responses that earn two points:

  • Adequately and successfully explain how the citation from the provided Latin text relates to the passage’s characterization of Athenodorus.

  • Relate the cited Latin to the prompt with substantive and sufficiently persuasive analysis in the explanation.
descriptions:
The response provides no explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Rather than losing his cool at the possibility of an encounter with a ghost, Athenodorus sets his mind to writing in order to avoid imagining something happening that isn’t (ipse ad scribendum…metus fingeret). In this we see his calmness on display.”

  • “Athenodorus plans to spend the night in the front of the house (iubet…parte) and sends everyone else away (suos omnes…dimittit). By doing this, he selflessly puts himself right where he expects the ghost to appear, while sparing everyone else the fright.”

Responses that do not earn this point.

  • Provide no explanation of the cited Latin.

  • Do not address the prompt in the explanation.

  • Do not address the specific Latin citation in the explanation.

  • Rely on incorrect assumptions about the Latin citation in the explanation.

The response provides one incomplete explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Examples that earn one point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Athenodorus plans to spend the night in the front of the house (iubet…parte) but sends everyone else away (suos omnes…dimittit). By sending everyone away to be alone, the passage depicts his character.”

  • “Athenodorus busies himself with writing in order to avoid getting unnecessarily afraid (ipse ad scibendum…metus fingeret). The fact that he knows ghosts are only ‘empty’ (inanes) figments shows his bravery.”

Additional Notes:

  • The explanation does not need to be in separate sentences. The Latin citation and the explanation of it can be contained in a single sentence (or multiple sentences).

Provides one complete explanation of how the cited Latin relates to the prompt.

Examples that earn two points include but are not limited to the following:

  • “Rather than losing his cool at the possibility of an encounter with a ghost, Athenodorus sets his mind to writing in order to avoid imagining something happening that isn’t (ipse ad scribendum…metus fingeret). In this we see his calmness on display.”

  • “Athenodorus plans to spend the night in the front of the house (iubet…parte) and sends everyone else away (suos omnes…dimittit). By doing this, he selflessly puts himself right where he expects the ghost to appear, while sparing everyone else the fright.”

Additional Notes:

  • The explanation does not need to be in separate sentences. The Latin citation and the explanation of it can be contained in a single sentence (or multiple sentences).
